name: electricity production, hydro, run-of-river | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/176/documentation

A modifier This dataset represents the production of 1kWh of electricity in a run-of-river hydropower power plant in Quebec in 2008. This dataset is based on study on the production, transmission and distribution of electricity in Quebec in the 2008-2013 period. It represents an average of all the run-of-river power plants that belong to Hydro-Quebec, which is the main electricity provider in the region (about 95% of the total electricity produced).  The inventory is based on a sample of 38 run-of-river power plants that combine for 13200MW, with different capacity (from 1800 MW to 4MW) and all the dams and derivations that were built to ensure the operation of the plants. Lifetime is assumed to be 100 years for the plant. Only main consumed products, wastes and emissions are included. Operation data were collected for the 2008-2013 period.;Baumann J. (1949) Kraftwerk Rupperswil-Auenstein. Verlag Kraftwerk;Rupperswil-Auenstein AG, Rupperswil.;Nordostschweizerische Kraftwerke AG (NOK) (1956) Das Kraftwerk;Wildegg-Brugg. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 74 (4), 47-52; 74 (5), 63-67; 74;(6), 83-88; 74 (7), 93-99; 74 (8), 111-116; 74 (10), 145-147; 74 (12), 167-172.;Aegerter A., Dr. Bosshardt O. (1954) Das Kraftwerk Birsfelden. In: Wasser- und;Energiewirtschaft, 46 (5-7), 165-176.;Brux G. (1983) Das Donaukraftwerk Greifenstein. In: Wasser, Energie, Luft, 75;(1-2), 11-13.;Radag A. (1979) 50 Jahre Rheinkraftwerk Albbruck-Dogern Aktiengesellschaft.;Waldshut/Rhein, 1929-1979.;Bundesamt für Energiewirtschaft (2001) Elektrizitatsstatistik 2000. Bern,;Schweiz.;Schweiz.;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

From (potential) energy in water, entering the power plant and use of power plant infrastructure.

The activity ends with 1 kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. 

The dataset includes main operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants, such as lubricating oil or mass of water passing through the turbines..

This dataset doesn"t include 
- land use for access roads to the power plant, raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets 
- transformation of the electricity produced.
- minor activities, materials and wastes.

C.F. Müller, Karlsruhe.;König F., von (1985) Bau von Wasserkraftanlagen. C.F. Müller, Karlsruhe.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: none. This dataset is based on a primary data collection
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data collection from the company including all its activities

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Total surface multiplied by the lifetime

Estimation. To estimate the area of the water courses (i.e. the section between the water inlet and the weir) the length and average width according to the map is multiplied. As a result an index (approximate value) is calculated where the facts that hydropower plants affect natural habitats and disturb ground water are accounted for. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 4,5 10^-3 m2a/kWh, the transformation of land amounts to 5,6 10^-3 m2a/kWh. Thereby major rivers show lower values than small ones. 

Due to the fact that the calculated value represents an index value, it is not a hundred per cent comparable with other information relating to areas. In Switzerland the area before operation of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation from pasture" and "transformation from shrub land". This is because of cultivated land reclamation reasons flood protection and drainage measures have been implemented in the past. Due to the fact that it is not allowed fertilizing the area bordering the river, this land is assumed to be shrub land. Thereby, a ratio of 50 % for shrub land and 50 % for pasture is estimated. 

The area after commissioning of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation to river, artificial". Land use for the weir and the power station is defined as "transformation to industrial area" at which 1 % of the value is defined for the water course. Land use for access roads can be neglected because most of the power plants are built on developed land. 

It has to be pointed out that run-of-river power plants do not necessarily have a negative impact on the ecological situation (e.g. new construction of the power plant Ruppoldingen).

Estimation. Data are adopted from the Swiss power plant sample as it stands, therefore uncertainty is increased. 

To estimate the area of the water courses (i.e. the section between the water inlet and the weir) the length and average width according to the map is multiplied. As a result an index (approximate value) is calculated where the facts that hydropower plants affect natural habitats and disturb ground water are accounted for. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 4,5 10^-3 m2a/kWh, the transformation of land amounts to 5,6 10^-3 m2a/kWh. Thereby major rivers show lower values than small ones. 

Due to the fact that the calculated value represents an index value, it is not a hundred per cent comparable with other information relating to areas. In Switzerland the area before operation of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation from pasture" and "transformation from shrub land". This is because of cultivated land reclamation reasons flood protection and drainage measures have been implemented in the past. Due to the fact that it is not allowed fertilizing the area bordering the river, this land is assumed to be shrub land. Thereby, a ratio of 50 % for shrub land and 50 % for pasture is estimated. 

The area after commissioning of the run-of-river plant is defined as "transformation to river, artificial". Land use for the weir and the power station is defined as "transformation to industrial area" at which 1 % of the value is defined for the water course. Land use for access roads can be neglected because most of the power plants are built on developed land. 

It has to be pointed out that run-of-river power plants do not necessarily have a negative impact on the ecological situation (e.g. new construction of the power plant Ruppoldingen).
